ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Linear algebra skills more applicable to real scenarios
Matrices (multiplication, inverses, transposes, determinants, diagonalization), eigenvalues and eigenvectors, Markov chains, orthogonalization
I developed basic skills in linear algebra like matrix manipulation, but the applications in engineering are somewhat few and far between.
Introduction to linear algebra tools (mainly matrices and their many uses, as well as eigenvalues/eigenvectors)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought it was paced pretty well and it was very clear what we needed to do

Strengths: straightforward lectures, problem sets helped further understanding of the material, interesting project
Weaknesses: lack of resources other than textbook
This course was a little hard to stay engaged in and I found that I learned quite a bit better from the textbook than from the lecture.

A strength was the pacing of the course, it felt like we covered a good amount of material without it being too fast or slow. A weakness is that it felt like there was a lack of uniformity between the different sections taught by different professors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is a pretty good introduction to linear algebra
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course for engineering students. Even though it is not required, it is very helpful for some of the later engineering courses. It is also well-taught.
I wasn't a big fan of this course just because it felt like class was not helpful and the midterm/final were super difficult, but you get out what you put in I guess.

Yes, it was very interesting and linear algebra has applications to many fields. It also felt more friendly toward those who aren't majoring in math or haven't taken it in a while compared to a different math course I had taken.
